Bug.Summery: Update FAQ with some of the thread on 'dynamic aspects' in AspectJ
Bug.WithStack:
Nicolas Lesiecki wrote:
Can I nominate a summary of this thread for inclusion in the FAQ? I think many users are under the mistaken impression that AspectJ provides poor support for dynamically changing aspect configuration and the solutions offered in this thread could help clear up these misconceptions.
Cheers, Nick On Mar 31, 2004, at 8:11 AM, Adrian Colyer wrote: Added Nicolas to cc list. P4ing and assigning to Wes, who was complicit in the thread in question. *smile*
fixed in faq.xml:1.23 - no summary, just discussion and references. It would still be nice to have more samples using dynamic techniques. Fix released as part of AspectJ 1.2.1

Can I nominate a summary of this thread for inclusion in the FAQ? I think many users are under the mistaken impression that AspectJ provides poor support for dynamically changing aspect configuration and the solutions offered in this thread could help clear up these misconceptions.

Bug.Summery: DBCS:Can not drop and drag DBCS name file from outside eclipse into pakage explore view of eclipse .

Lines.Line: 2-Drag and drop it at package explore view of eclipse.
Can not drop and drag DBCS name file from outside eclipse into pakage
The DBCS name file can be droped and draged into pakage explore view
moving to FH, I've verified that this works in english

Bug.WithStack:
Reporter: Tony Liu OS: SLES 9.0 Beta3-gtk Language: KOR Build level: wswb-I20040413-200404191247 JDK Version: IBM JDK 1.4.2 Beta Test case #: SWT 22 Summary: DBCS:Can not drop and drag DBCS name file from outside eclipse into pakage explore view of eclipse . Description: Steps to recreate problem: 1-Have DBCS named file outside eclipse. 2-Drag and drop it at package explore view of eclipse. <<Error>> Can not drop and drag DBCS name file from outside eclipse into pakage explore view of eclipse . <<Expected Result>> The DBCS name file can be droped and draged into pakage explore view of eclipse moving to FH, I've verified that this works in english
VI, any ideas ?
Running on Simplified Chinese. In /tmp dir of my machine I created and new Folder (chinese characters). If I try to drag this folder into Eclipse it fails. The URI for this folder is (as returned by Nautilus): "file:///tmp/%CE%B4%C3%FC%C3%FB%CE%C4%BC%FE%BC%D0" If I paste this string in mozilla navegation bar it opens the folder correctly, if I paste it in nautilus it also works. So I believe this URI is correct.
But, if use the call g_filename_from_uri() to parse this URI it returns a error message: The URI 'file:///tmp/%CE%B4%C3%FC%C3%FB%CE%C4%BC%FE%BC%D0' contains invalidly escaped characters
This is what is causing Eclipse to fail, g_filename_from_uri() is the function that SWT uses to parte URIs.
This kind of looks like a bug in g_filename_from_uri(). I reported a bug against Glib: http://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=140980 I have verified this problem is fixed in GTK 2.4.7/Glib 2.4.6 Closing pr
Bug.WithOutStack:
Reporter: Tony Liu OS: SLES 9.0 Beta3-gtk Language: KOR Build level: wswb-I20040413-200404191247 JDK Version: IBM JDK 1.4.2 Beta Test case #: SWT 22 Summary: DBCS:Can not drop and drag DBCS name file from outside eclipse into pakage explore view of eclipse . Description: Steps to recreate problem: 1-Have DBCS named file outside eclipse. 2-Drag and drop it at package explore view of eclipse. <<Error>> Can not drop and drag DBCS name file from outside eclipse into pakage explore view of eclipse . <<Expected Result>> The DBCS name file can be droped and draged into pakage explore view of eclipse moving to FH, I've verified that this works in english
VI, any ideas ?
Running on Simplified Chinese. In /tmp dir of my machine I created and new Folder (chinese characters). If I try to drag this folder into Eclipse it fails. The URI for this folder is (as returned by Nautilus): "file:///tmp/%CE%B4%C3%FC%C3%FB%CE%C4%BC%FE%BC%D0" If I paste this string in mozilla navegation bar it opens the folder correctly, if I paste it in nautilus it also works. So I believe this URI is correct.
But, if use the call g_filename_from_uri() to parse this URI it returns a error message: The URI 'file:///tmp/%CE%B4%C3%FC%C3%FB%CE%C4%BC%FE%BC%D0' contains invalidly escaped characters
This is what is causing Eclipse to fail, g_filename_from_uri() is the function that SWT uses to parte URIs.
This kind of looks like a bug in g_filename_from_uri(). I reported a bug against Glib: http://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=140980 I have verified this problem is fixed in GTK 2.4.7/Glib 2.4.6 Closing pr

Bug.Summery: Perf: JavaCommandStackPropertySheetEntry gets name and value often
Bug.WithStack: Noticed this doing debugging. The JavaCommandStackPropertySheetEntry (mainly via inherited code) called getText(Object) 3 times for every property when a JavaBean is selected, and also calls getName() several times. getText(Object) often requires a VM round trip, and getName() requires searching decorator lists. For performance it seems that the entry could cache these. I also am having second thoughts about the property descriptor caching the label provider instance. Instead we should change it to cache the method proxy used to create it - it will mean that people can hold onto values if they want to, and the real problem isn't that construction was slow, it was that it occured too often. Performance
Bug.WithOutStack: Noticed this doing debugging. The JavaCommandStackPropertySheetEntry (mainly via inherited code) called getText(Object) 3 times for every property when a JavaBean is selected, and also calls getName() several times. getText(Object) often requires a VM round trip, and getName() requires searching decorator lists. For performance it seems that the entry could cache these. I also am having second thoughts about the property descriptor caching the label provider instance. Instead we should change it to cache the method proxy used to create it - it will mean that people can hold onto values if they want to, and the real problem isn't that construction was slow, it was that it occured too often. Performance

Bug.Summery: Weaver fails in BCEL for large classes

Stacktrace.Reason: Expected class `CONSTANT_Utf8' at index 25700 and got CONSTANT_NameAndType[12](name_index = 25696, signature_index = 81)
Class can't be both final and abstract

Lines.Line: 1. Compile and run the following code to produce Foo.java

Bug.WithStack:
This problem was first observed when weaving large binary legacy classes with the ajc 1.2 rc1 candidate. It turns out that BCEL fails with different error messages dependent on whether we are doing a binary weave or a straight ajc compile. In the latter case, the error message is rather confusing.
To reproduce: 1. Compile and run the following code to produce Foo.java // File FooProducer.java public class FooProducer { public static final int N_METHODS = 50; public static final int N_STATEMENTS = Short.MAX_VALUE/(2 * N_METHODS); public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("public class Foo {"); System.out.println("static java.util.Set hs = new java.util.HashSet ();"); for (int i = 0; i < N_METHODS; i++) { System.out.println("public void test" + i + "() { "); for (int j = 0; j < N_STATEMENTS; j++) { System.out.println("hs.add(new Object());"); } System.out.println("}"); } System.out.println("}"); } }// End of FooProducer.java
2. Create the following Aspect: // File a.aj aspect a { boolean around() : (target(java.util.HashSet) && call(boolean add(..) ) ) { return false; } } // End of a.aj
*** 3.a - straight compile and weave: ajc - sourceroots .
ABORT
Exception thrown from AspectJ 1.2rc1
This might be logged as a bug already -- find current bugs at http://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/buglist.cgi?product=AspectJ&component=Compiler
Bugs for exceptions thrown have titles File:line from the top stack, e.g., "SomeFile.java:243"
If you don't find the exception below in a bug, please add a new bug at http://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/enter_bug.cgi?product=AspectJ To make the bug a priority, please include a test program that can reproduce this exception. 1 fail|abort Signal 127 Seems like the bug is caused by a truncation of the ConstantPool unsigned short limit of 65535 when BcelClassWeaver writes the bytecode after weaving. I.e. this happens when the ConstantPool size is larger than 65535.
There is not much ajc can do about that limit but I propose that a more meaningful error message is generated by the weaver in this case. In both scenarios the compilation will now fail cleanly with an error message:
The class Foo exceeds the maximum class size supported by the JVM (constant pool too big).
Will close this bug once the fix is available in a published build. Thanks for the clear test case. Fix now available in latest build on AspectJ download page. Fix released as part of AspectJ 1.2.1
Bug.WithOutStack:
This problem was first observed when weaving large binary legacy classes with the ajc 1.2 rc1 candidate. It turns out that BCEL fails with different error messages dependent on whether we are doing a binary weave or a straight ajc compile. In the latter case, the error message is rather confusing.
To reproduce: 1. Compile and run the following code to produce Foo.java // File FooProducer.java public class FooProducer { public static final int N_METHODS = 50; public static final int N_STATEMENTS = Short.MAX_VALUE/(2 * N_METHODS); public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("public class Foo {"); System.out.println("static java.util.Set hs = new java.util.HashSet ();"); for (int i = 0; i < N_METHODS; i++) { System.out.println("public void test" + i + "() { "); for (int j = 0; j < N_STATEMENTS; j++) { System.out.println("hs.add(new Object());"); } System.out.println("}"); } System.out.println("}"); } }// End of FooProducer.java
2. Create the following Aspect: // File a.aj aspect a { boolean around() : (target(java.util.HashSet) && call(boolean add(..) ) ) { return false; } } // End of a.aj
*** 3.a - straight compile and weave: ajc - sourceroots .

Bug.Summery: [Dialogs] 'Open Resource' dialog lists /classes before /src

Lines.Line: 1) Source folders should *always* be listed before other folders, and output
folders last after other folders, for resources of the same name.
2) Resources which are included by copying during the build process, should
behave as (generally) as derivative since, even though bytes are not different,
they are not the primary information. (Actually bytes are only constant under
static conditions; it's the transitive conditions making the bytes differ which

Bug.WithStack:
The 'Open Resource' ctrl-shift-R dialog lists /classes before /src resources.
It seems to work alright for Java files which it may know to be 'derived' by the compilation process, but for resources in /classes which were 'derived' by simple copying to output folder build time it does not behave correctly or usefully.
Eg with ANTLR .g grammar files, it is very common to edit the copied output resource by mistake; work then being immediately lost when one tries to build from these changes.
So really 2 points:
1) Source folders should *always* be listed before other folders, and output folders last after other folders, for resources of the same name.
2) Resources which are included by copying during the build process, should behave as (generally) as derivative since, even though bytes are not different, they are not the primary information. (Actually bytes are only constant under static conditions; it's the transitive conditions making the bytes differ which is causing the problem here).
Cheers, Thomas
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 3905 *** Reopening - wrong dup
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 34905 ***
Bug.WithOutStack:
The 'Open Resource' ctrl-shift-R dialog lists /classes before /src resources.
It seems to work alright for Java files which it may know to be 'derived' by the compilation process, but for resources in /classes which were 'derived' by simple copying to output folder build time it does not behave correctly or usefully.
Eg with ANTLR .g grammar files, it is very common to edit the copied output resource by mistake; work then being immediately lost when one tries to build from these changes.
So really 2 points:
1) Source folders should *always* be listed before other folders, and output folders last after other folders, for resources of the same name.
2) Resources which are included by copying during the build process, should behave as (generally) as derivative since, even though bytes are not different, they are not the primary information. (Actually bytes are only constant under static conditions; it's the transitive conditions making the bytes differ which is causing the problem here).
Cheers, Thomas

Bug.Summery: FontEditor and ColorEditor - do not open on selection of current value
Bug.WithStack:
Open Font Editor - lists are de-selected. It should try to match the current font against the values so the user can see the existing font - useful if you just want to do something like bold it without having to re-select the family, size, etc... Likewise for ColorEditor Current values are now selected when dialog appears. On creation of the dialog, current values are resolved using the bean proxies.
Plugin: org.eclipse.ve.swt Affected files: ColorPropertyEditor.java; FontPropertyEditor.java 1.0M2 is out, so these are now closed in M2.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Open Font Editor - lists are de-selected. It should try to match the current font against the values so the user can see the existing font - useful if you just want to do something like bold it without having to re-select the family, size, etc... Likewise for ColorEditor Current values are now selected when dialog appears. On creation of the dialog, current values are resolved using the bean proxies.
Plugin: org.eclipse.ve.swt Affected files: ColorPropertyEditor.java; FontPropertyEditor.java 1.0M2 is out, so these are now closed in M2.

Bug.Summery: Drop control in null layout -should set to preferred size
Bug.WithStack: Drop a control without dragging a size and it can't be seen (the size is 0,0) What VE Swing does is set the size to be -1,-1 (or Integer.MIN_VALUE ?) in the edit policy, and the proxy adapter picks these up and then gets the current preferred size from the target VM (which can only be computed after it has been added to the parent) and sets them so the user sees a good initial size. We should do the same for SWT *** Bug 64375 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Please see if this is still a problem on the current code base. I believe the code was applied and committed. Please check and move to resolved/fix if it is. Thanks.. fixed Setting to 1.0M3 for ship. Now that 1.0 is released, marking as verified. Now that 1.0 is released, marking as closed.

We should do the same for SWT *** Bug 64375 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Please see if this is still a problem on the current code base. Bug.Summery: TableTree should support setBackground(int, Color) etc.
Bug.WithStack:
Behaviour observed in 3.0M8.
When setting color on cells or rows in the underlying table using (for instance) getTable().getItems()[x].setBackground(y,Color), the TableTree control disregards this when collapsing/expanding the tree.
Check out the attached example (if I manage to attach it properly):
By collapsing and expanding the tree, the beautiful yellow background color of the cell with "val4" in "Col2" disappears.
A workaround for this is to make the coloring happen in a TreeListener.
My suggestion to the SWT team is to introduce individual cell coloring on TableTreeItems (analogous to TableItems).
It would be nice if this kind of functionality also was available via the viewers, for instance with a new ITableColorProvider interface.
Cheers, Emil Einarsson Created attachment 9691 Java source to observe the problem
Source code to observe the problem in action. This is incorrect use of TableTree. You must never reach down and access the underlying TableItems for any reason.
The correct way to set the colour for individual cells is through API on TableTreeItem. Currently TableTreeItem supports setFont, setBackground and setForeground for the entire row but not for individual cells.
This should not be a bug report but an enhancement request for this new API. *** Bug 68453 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** In 3.1, please use Tree with TreeColumns. It uses the native widget.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Behaviour observed in 3.0M8.
When setting color on cells or rows in the underlying table using (for instance) getTable().getItems()[x].setBackground(y,Color), the TableTree control disregards this when collapsing/expanding the tree.
Check out the attached example (if I manage to attach it properly):
By collapsing and expanding the tree, the beautiful yellow background color of the cell with "val4" in "Col2" disappears.
A workaround for this is to make the coloring happen in a TreeListener.
My suggestion to the SWT team is to introduce individual cell coloring on TableTreeItems (analogous to TableItems).
It would be nice if this kind of functionality also was available via the viewers, for instance with a new ITableColorProvider interface.
Cheers, Emil Einarsson Created attachment 9691 Java source to observe the problem
Source code to observe the problem in action. This is incorrect use of TableTree. You must never reach down and access the underlying TableItems for any reason.
The correct way to set the colour for individual cells is through API on TableTreeItem. Currently TableTreeItem supports setFont, setBackground and setForeground for the entire row but not for individual cells.
This should not be a bug report but an enhancement request for this new API. *** Bug 68453 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** In 3.1, please use Tree with TreeColumns. It uses the native widget.

Bug.Summery: DBCS: local icon not shown at Run wizard

Lines.Line: 1-perform Hyades3.0 recorder and testgen NLS input
2-Run Hyades URL test suite from context menu

Bug.WithStack:
OS: Windows2003 Standard Edition Language: Japanese Build level: 20040419_0915(wswb-I20040413-200404191247) JDK Version: IBM JDK 1.4.2 Beta Test case #: Hyades HTTP Test 3.0 Test cases
Description: Steps to recreate problem: 1-perform Hyades3.0 recorder and testgen NLS input 2-Run Hyades URL test suite from context menu 3-remove / from the name (please refer bug 59222)
<<error>> local icon is not shown <<Expected Result>> local icon should be shown Created attachment 9692 screen shot I'm not sure what "local icon" means. I'm assuming that you mean a deployment/location.
Be sure that a deployment, location & artifact/location pair have been created & correctly associated with the deployment. Then the deployment should be able to be shown.
Test.HTTP borrows completely from test.java for this dialog. Reassigning component (although I suspect this bug is really user error).
Also, be aware that the Run dialog is being phased out for Launch Configuration. This defect may be rendered irrelevant. Fixed with the new Launch Configuration closing. verified in 20040506

<<error>> local icon is not shown <<Expected Result>> local icon should be shown Created attachment 9692 screen shot I'm not sure what "local icon" means. I'm assuming that you mean a deployment/location.
Be sure that a deployment, location & artifact/location pair have been created & correctly associated with the deployment. Then the deployment should be able to be shown.
Test.HTTP borrows completely from test.java for this dialog. Reassigning component (although I suspect this bug is really user error).

Bug.Summery: [C/C++ Projects View] No way to identify binary from configuration in Binaries folder
Bug.WithStack:
Eclipse 200404131323 CDT 200404190838
In the C/C++ Projects View, the binaries folder is listing all the binaries for all the configurations of a project. But the UI is not intuitive for the user to match the binary with the configuration.
Recommendation: we should display the path from project directory where each binary comes from. It should be on the status line message below, if you select them.
Obviously, you are tell me that is not enough 8-). We'll try to come up with more visual clues. PR was not targeted to any particular release. Changing target milestone to 2.1 Assuming that my work around was enough(since no feeback from the original reporter).

Bug.Summery: DBCS: compare improperly in EUC-JP encoding project on workbench encoding MS932

Lines.Line: 1-create java program on RHEL 3.0WS Japanese locale (workbench default encoding
2-create java project on windows2003 (workench default encoding is MS932), and
change EUC-JP at the project properties > info page
3-import the java programs into the project
4-edit a text in comment, and save

Bug.WithStack:
OS: Windows2003 Standard Edition Language: Japanese Build level: wswb-I20040413-200404191247 JDK Version: IBM JDK 1.4.2 Beta Test case #:
Description: Steps to recreate problem: 1-create java program on RHEL 3.0WS Japanese locale (workbench default encoding is EUC-JP). 2-create java project on windows2003 (workench default encoding is MS932), and change EUC-JP at the project properties > info page 3-import the java programs into the project 4-edit a text in comment, and save 5-compare from local history
<<error>> bogus all of Japanese text in the file at local history and they are indicated as changed. Created attachment 9697 sample java programs Created attachment 9698 screen shot Moving to Platform/Compare. Please try opening bugs against the specific component. The problem is that FileState.getCharset() returns null in this case. I suggest to return the getCharset() of the associated IFile. Moving to platform.core
Andre, I would say that when someone calls IFileState#getCharset, that information should be extracted from the state itself, and not default to the corresponding file's charset.
We already have bug 61986 (the one this depends on) for the issue with states not remembering their charsets at the time they were created. Even when that one is fixed, I would not expect the corresponding file to be queried anyway.
Isn't there anything you can do on your side to work around bug 61986? For instance, you could do the same thing you suggested (default to the corresponding file's charset), or allow the user to manually select a different charset to use when reading a given state.
If it cannot be worked around, feel free to mark this one as a duplicate of bug 61986.
Moving back (again!) to Compare for comments/further action. I had the impression that delegating the IFileState.getCharset request to the IFile would be a better approximation of the desired behavior than the current implementation.
Yes, I can try to workaround this problem in my code (and all other clients need to do the same). fixed for RC2 verified in 3.0 and closing

OS: Windows2003 Standard Edition Language: Japanese Build level: wswb-I20040413-200404191247 JDK Version: IBM JDK 1.4.2 Beta Test case #:

You can't have a horizontal scroll bar in a combo box.

Bug.Summery: Rulers and snapping enhancements.

Lines.Line: 1. There is need to have several vertical rulers that are tied to the
2. Rulers do not always originate from the container origin.
3. Ruler marks are not always numbers.
4. Rulers must have different appearance from the GEF (grayed print margins,
5. Rulers can have different coordinates in the viewer when it is resized.
1. Rulers were splitted and some interfaces were extracted, namely
IRulerEditPart and IOrientableFigure - this allows to provide totally custom
implementation that fits well with the RulerComposite, Drag tracker, layout,
etc. It is now possible to provide custom edit part factory to RulerComposite
that will create custom edit parts.
3. AbstractRulerFigure method can be overriden to provide different mark names.
5. Some coordinate tweaking is made. Guide edit part now listens to the viewer

Bug.WithStack:
In our project we have following requirements: 1. There is need to have several vertical rulers that are tied to the individual containers. 2. Rulers do not always originate from the container origin. 3. Ruler marks are not always numbers. 4. Rulers must have different appearance from the GEF (grayed print margins, etc.) 5. Rulers can have different coordinates in the viewer when it is resized.
Snapping requirement: There are custom requests that must also be snapped. Created attachment 9701 Patch to logic example to work with the new rulers. Created attachment 9702 Patch to update rulers API I've made following changes in the GEF rulers implementation: 1. Rulers were splitted and some interfaces were extracted, namely IRulerEditPart and IOrientableFigure - this allows to provide totally custom implementation that fits well with the RulerComposite, Drag tracker, layout, etc. It is now possible to provide custom edit part factory to RulerComposite that will create custom edit parts. 2. AbstractRulerFigure supports origin different from 0. 3. AbstractRulerFigure method can be overriden to provide different mark names. 4. See point 1. 5. Some coordinate tweaking is made. Guide edit part now listens to the viewer resizes.
Snapping: Interface for the requests that have snapping rectangle was added, snap strategies support snapping for this request and LocationRequest. (I haven't yet implemented snapping to geometry for these requests - I'll do it a bit later) SnapFeedback now tries to highlight snapping for all request types. Created attachment 9850 Newer version of the GEF patch to include new ruler API
There was a major testing of the rulers, grid and snapping and this is fix for the issues encountered (i.e. some coordinates are not correctly translated, etc.)
Also location request cannot be snapped as is so I added new class - SnappableLocationRequest. The only difference is that this request provides list of the edit parts that should be omitted when snapping to geometry. BTW connection bendpoints can be easily updated to be snapped as the connection bendpoint request extends LocationRequest. Pratik, look at these changes when you have time. Created attachment 9993 Patch to the most recent GEF (changes made to head were merged with my version, testing was performed) Created attachment 10098 Patch was updated with the lates changes in GEF.
Please, if it is possible, tell us if we can expect this patch to be accepted as a part of GEF SDK (and tell what changes are to be made) or we should fork the API so we will use our own Rulers / snapping support and the GEF SDK (even though in our application we rely on snapping the location request that is not supported by the current GEF SnapTo implementations). Problem is that we cannot use GEF from the eclipse.org / Eclipse CVS and this can cause problems with other plugins. I took a look at your patch, and I can tell you right off the bat that not all these changes will make it into the GEF 3.0 release. That doesn't mean that we won't consider it for GEF, but that it probably will not get into this upcoming release. We want to rework/improve some of these new features based on feedback and how clients (like you) are using it. Exposing code or introducing interfaces makes it difficult to change things in the future. That's part of the reason why the code behind some features (rulers/guides, for instance) is hidden.
I am still looking at some of the other changes. More details to follow. But given that we have one week of development time left to be function-complete, things don't look too promising. Ok, I see, though you can see from the changes in the Logic example that little was changed in the interfaces. I've only added more facilities for the customization - and I am sure that most users won't use them.
I don't think it would be a problem to fork the rulers - but please take a look to 2 new methods in the snapping strategies - it would be hard to fork them. So I moved all the updated code to our project so we now run on unmodified GEF and I hope that this issue will be checked for the next release of GEF - I'll try to track the changes in the GEF CVS so the patch will be available.
As for the snapping - it seems like it is necessary to add translateToParent when translating to absolute (I did so in my code and it helped to fix some issues) What do you use snapRectangleRequest(...) for? That's our own request - I just wanted to offer some generic requests that can be snapped. But it's a matter of the discussion. I think that all requests (judjing from our application) that are to be snapped can be divided into recatangle request (can be snapped on four sides, like creation request, move request) and location requests (DnD requests, connection bendpoint moved request, resize request)... But there can be other types/particular cases. Just as an update, I have changed the snap API so that it's generic enough to snap a variety of requests (although I have not used your code). But I need to do a whole lot of testing before I can release it. It should be out next week. I have released the new snap API in the CVS repository (although it hasn't made it into a build yet). SnapToHelper is now an abstract class that has two public methods: snapLocation() and snapRectangle(). The API should be fairly stable, although there might be a few minor changes before the final 3.0 release.
There were a couple of comments (here and on the newsgroup) about the snap classes not converting the given bounds to relative properly. I have looked into it and it seems we cannot have a common conversion for every case possible, considering that clients are drifting from the intended usage of some of these features. To accommodate for this, I have separated the conversion into two separate methods (makeRelative and makeAbsolute) which clients can override as needed.
Euguene, can you catch up with the repository and see if this new API serves all your needs? FYI, the new snap API made it into the I20040513 build. LATER and REMIND resolutions will be going away with the upgrade of Bugzilla to the latest Bugzilla 3.4. They are no longer part of the default Bugzilla installation. See http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/eclipse.org-committers/msg00778.html for the announcement.
As a result RESOLVED + REMIND OR LATER will be changed to RESOLVED + WONTFIX
This unfortunately also means I need to REOPEN and then RESOLVE as WONTFIX

I've only added more facilities for the customization - and I am sure that most users won't use them.
I don't think it would be a problem to fork the rulers - but please take a look to 2 new methods in the snapping strategies - it would be hard to fork them. So I moved all the updated code to our project so we now run on unmodified GEF and I hope that this issue will be checked for the next release of GEF - I'll try to track the changes in the GEF CVS so the patch will be available.
As for the snapping - it seems like it is necessary to add translateToParent when translating to absolute (I did so in my code and it helped to fix some issues) What do you use snapRectangleRequest(...) for? That's our own request - I just wanted to offer some generic requests that can be snapped. But it's a matter of the discussion. I think that all requests (judjing from our application) that are to be snapped can be divided into recatangle request (can be snapped on four sides, like creation request, move request) and location requests (DnD requests, connection bendpoint moved request, resize request)... But there can be other types/particular cases. Just as an update, I have changed the snap API so that it's generic enough to snap a variety of requests (although I have not used your code). But I need to do a whole lot of testing before I can release it. It should be out next week. I have released the new snap API in the CVS repository (although it hasn't made it into a build yet). SnapToHelper is now an abstract class that has two public methods: snapLocation() and snapRectangle(). The API should be fairly stable, although there might be a few minor changes before the final 3.0 release.
There were a couple of comments (here and on the newsgroup) about the snap classes not converting the given bounds to relative properly. I have looked into it and it seems we cannot have a common conversion for every case possible, considering that clients are drifting from the intended usage of some of these features. To accommodate for this, I have separated the conversion into two separate methods (makeRelative and makeAbsolute) which clients can override as needed.
Euguene, can you catch up with the repository and see if this new API serves all your needs? FYI, the new snap API made it into the I20040513 build. Bug.Summery: Support for virtual spaces in editors
Bug.WithStack:
Request: I would like support for what Microsoft calls "virtual spaces" in the source editor classes. What this means is that the text cursor can be moved on a line beyond where there is actual character data. The cursor cannot be moved to a line beyond the end of the data. Each additional unit where you can move the cursor is the width of a space in whatever font the editor is using, hence the term virtual space. Mouse clicks would be accepted as well. If the cursor is out in virtual space, then typing a character would cause padding space to be added up to the actual character data. Care must be taken when doing a clipboard copy or handling edits to handle the virtual positions correctly. Non-monospaced fonts require some cursor positioning care. Home and end key behavior would be unaffected. This would be a mode that you can flip on and off and is language independent.
Justification: I find it annoying to be moving the cursor up and down in the text and have the cursor moving right and left (and worse, horizontal editor scrolling) because of the inability to put the cursor at the current column on the current line. Also, I believe the way Eclipse works now when you hit a return is to add the correct number of spaces for the indent to the next line. This can lead to a lot of extra whitespace in the file (which I assume can be removed with the formatter). However, with virtual space support you could calculate the indent and simply place the cursor there without actually adding the whitespace. When/if they type a character, you would fill in with padding whitespace (at the beginning of a line, using tabs/spaces as set).
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 21000 ***

Bug.Summery: BasicCommandStack.flush() method doesn't reset mostRecentCommand
Bug.WithStack: In the flush() method, the mostRecentCommand is not set to null, it does not seem coherent. The fix has been commited to CVS. The fix is available in the I200404281648 build. Move to verified as per bug 206558. Why is the mostRecentCommand set to null AFTER notifying the command stack listeners and not before the call to notifyListeners()? Its hard for a CommandStackListener to distinguish whether its commandStackChanged() method was called from the (Basic)CommandStack because of an actual command execution (execute, redo, undo) or because of flushing the CommandStack. A simple workaround is to cache the last mostRecentCommand in the CommandStackListener and do a simple reference check against the the "new" mostRecentCommand. But this does not consider the fact, that commands are stateful (executed, undone, redone). If the mostRecentCommand in the BasicCommandStack would be set to null before notifying the command stack listeners these listeners would be able to realize that the command stack has been flushed. I think you're right. It would seem better to do all state changes before the notification. Please open a new bugzilla and I'll change it. (In reply to comment #5) > Please open a new bugzilla and I'll change it. https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=345520
Bug.WithOutStack: In the flush() method, the mostRecentCommand is not set to null, it does not seem coherent. The fix has been commited to CVS. The fix is available in the I200404281648 build. Move to verified as per bug 206558. Why is the mostRecentCommand set to null AFTER notifying the command stack listeners and not before the call to notifyListeners()? Its hard for a CommandStackListener to distinguish whether its commandStackChanged() method was called from the (Basic)CommandStack because of an actual command execution (execute, redo, undo) or because of flushing the CommandStack. A simple workaround is to cache the last mostRecentCommand in the CommandStackListener and do a simple reference check against the the "new" mostRecentCommand. But this does not consider the fact, that commands are stateful (executed, undone, redone). If the mostRecentCommand in the BasicCommandStack would be set to null before notifying the command stack listeners these listeners would be able to realize that the command stack has been flushed. I think you're right. It would seem better to do all state changes before the notification. Please open a new bugzilla and I'll change it. (In reply to comment #5) > Please open a new bugzilla and I'll change it. https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=345520

Bug.Summery: [launching] Enhance control for saving dirty editors and waiting for build before launch
Bug.WithStack:
There are some launch configuration global preferences (under Window -> Preferences -> Run/Debug) that aren't really universally applicable to both out-of-process program launching and in-process script launching:
* Build (if required) before launching. * Wait for ongoing build to complete before launching. * Save dirty editors before launching.
For example, users tend to want dirty editors to be saved before launching a program out-of-process so that the launched process can use/access up to date resources. This is because it has no access to the dirty resources in the launching shell. However, the same is not true for scripts, which do have access to the dirty resources in the shell's workspace. Users most likely will prefer that only dirty _script_ editors be saved when a script is launched, since scripts will commonly make modifications to working copies (i.e. dirty copies) of resources in the workspace that should not necessarily be saved automatically (i.e. running a script is like running other workbench menu items that make modifications to the workspace without causing a Save All). For example, it's easy to envision a script that makes a special modification to some selected text in the active text editor. Invoking such a script should not cause all dirty editors to be saved. Deferred. As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

For example, it's easy to envision a script that makes a special modification to some selected text in the active text editor. Invoking such a script should not cause all dirty editors to be saved. Deferred. As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: NoClassDefFoundError not being displayed in console

Lines.Line: 1. Start Eclipse in a new workspace.
2. Create a new "External Java Application" profiling configuration. Specify a
non-existent class, and a non-existent classpath. Click Run.

Bug.WithStack:
Found in Hyades 3.0 20040419_0915 driver.
Steps to reproduce: ------------------- 1. Start Eclipse in a new workspace. 2. Create a new "External Java Application" profiling configuration. Specify a non-existent class, and a non-existent classpath. Click Run.
You will see that (for some reason) there is data in the Package Statistics view, but more importantly, the console is greyed, with no data.
There should be a java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError or something similar to indicate to the user that the specified class/classpath is invalid. As it is right now, a user might think that the program executed for a fraction of a second, got some data, then exited (which is NOT the case). The problem here is that the ILaunch is being removed immediately when the application terminates. This removes the console data along with it (including the NoClassDefFound error).
The package statistics view should still contain some data, because the JVM has to do a certain amount of work before it loads the main class. An example of this would be loading a class loader, which is a class in itself.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 58399 *** Closing bug, since original has been fixed. house keeping

The package statistics view should still contain some data, because the JVM has to do a certain amount of work before it loads the main class. An example of this would be loading a class loader, which is a class in itself.

Bug.Summery: [ManagedBuild] Being able to change "Debug"/"Release" default configurations creates problems with Restore Defaults

Lines.Line: 1) In the C/C++ Build properties, select "Release"
3) Click "Apply". Now "Release" contains a non-default option.
1) Clone Debug configuration and name it Debug1
2) Set the current configuration to Debug1
3) Make a change to the configuration

Bug.WithStack:
Eclipse 200404131323 CDT 200404190838
When apply changes to "Debug" or "Release" default configurations, it creates problems when you press "Restore Defaults".
Steps: 1) In the C/C++ Build properties, select "Release" 2) Change any option 3) Click "Apply". Now "Release" contains a non-default option. 4) Click "Restore Defaults" 5) Re-select the "Release" configuration
The "Command" and "All Options" UI disappears. Adding to this bug:
Restore Defaults not working on Cloned Configuration. It stays the same as the applied one.
Steps: 1) Clone Debug configuration and name it Debug1 2) Set the current configuration to Debug1 3) Make a change to the configuration 4) Optional: hit "Apply" 5) Hit "Restore Defaults"
Nothing happens even if we don't do 4). Expected: Should it revert to the default "Debug" Configuration?
Note: Restore Defaults works on default configuration "Debug" and "Release" Raised to P2 since it failed a Test case (thus affecting the pass rate). Revert back to P3 (non-gating) The second problem reported was the result of an NPE during the reset. When I cloned the configs, I was using the ID of the settings "donor", but the donor was not one of the default configurations from the plugin file, so the build system was getting pooched trying to find it. Addressed this for now by properly identifying the original settings donor so resetting will work corrrectly.
I suspect that the first report was also a result of this, since I can not duplicate it. Verified Eclipse 200406111814 CDT 200406160301
Bug.WithOutStack:
Eclipse 200404131323 CDT 200404190838
When apply changes to "Debug" or "Release" default configurations, it creates problems when you press "Restore Defaults".
Steps: 1) In the C/C++ Build properties, select "Release" 2) Change any option 3) Click "Apply". Now "Release" contains a non-default option. 4) Click "Restore Defaults" 5) Re-select the "Release" configuration
The "Command" and "All Options" UI disappears. Adding to this bug:
Restore Defaults not working on Cloned Configuration. It stays the same as the applied one.
Steps: 1) Clone Debug configuration and name it Debug1 2) Set the current configuration to Debug1 3) Make a change to the configuration 4) Optional: hit "Apply" 5) Hit "Restore Defaults"
Nothing happens even if we don't do 4). Expected: Should it revert to the default "Debug" Configuration?
Note: Restore Defaults works on default configuration "Debug" and "Release" Raised to P2 since it failed a Test case (thus affecting the pass rate). Revert back to P3 (non-gating) The second problem reported was the result of an NPE during the reset. When I cloned the configs, I was using the ID of the settings "donor", but the donor was not one of the default configurations from the plugin file, so the build system was getting pooched trying to find it. Addressed this for now by properly identifying the original settings donor so resetting will work corrrectly.
I suspect that the first report was also a result of this, since I can not duplicate it. Verified Eclipse 200406111814 CDT 200406160301

Bug.Summery: Test Connection button caching results based on host

Lines.Line: 3. Go to Window -> Preferences -> Profiling & Logging -> Hosts.
7. Test Connection. You should get a RAC not started message (this is good).
9. Select localhost:10002, Test Connection. Should see connection success.

Bug.WithStack:
Found in Hyades 3.0 20040419_0915 driver.
Steps to reproduce: ------------------- 1. Start Eclipse. 2. Stop RAC. 3. Go to Window -> Preferences -> Profiling & Logging -> Hosts. 4. Delete localhost:10002 5. Add localhost:10003 6. Start RAC. 7. Test Connection. You should get a RAC not started message (this is good). 8. Add localhost:10002 9. Select localhost:10002, Test Connection. Should see connection success. 10. Select localhost:10003, Test Connection.
You will see that this *also* gives Connection Success, but it shouldn't, since there's nothing listening to port 10003!! The only conclusion that I could draw from this is that it is somehow caching the connection success from localhost:10002, and saying that for 10003 also.
Even worse, if you then delete localhost:10002 (leaving localhsot:10003 as the only one left), and then do Test Connection, it *still* says Connection Success!

Bug.Summery: Need to get back the "1 wizard to n extension-point" capability in the New Extension Wizard

Lines.Line: 1) Templates are mapped 1->1 with extension points. This mapping is
not in the template declaration in plugin.xml. This mapping should be added
2) By declaring the mapping in 1), we should drop 'contributingId' in
extension wizard extension point because it wrongly implies that this wizard
can contribute only one extension. Instead, we should change the behaviour of
the attribute 'template' from 'boolean' (is/is not a template) to string
(template id). This way, one can either define 'class' attribute (we will use
it as a wizard), or 'template' attribute. In the later case, the value would
be the ID of the template registered elsewhere using the 'templates' extension
point. By looking up the template, we will be able to get the contributingId
from it, so the current code will work normally.
3) The current page is very good and useful for most of the users. I would not
complicate the dialog any further by adding categories etc. Right now, the
selector is extension point, for which we check if there are templates with
the matching contributing id. I propose that we add a tabbed folder to the
wizard, with the first tab being the current content, and the second one being
custom wizards. Alternatively, we can have a tree view and with two root nodes
corresponding to the two tabs. However, in this particular case I would like
to make the most common case the default i.e. to prevent adding mouse clicks
to get to the most common state.
1) Templates several levels deep in the hierarchy are all found and shown in
2) All the wizards are properly show up in the second tab under their
3) The description in the wizard makes sense for all the selections in all the
4) Wizard buttons properly enable/disable based on the selection in the tabs.
1) A number of templates is registered with a category c1/c2/c3
2) The second page (category-based) should show the template wizards when c3
is selected in the left pane
3) The first page should show the templates declared under c3 when the
Ran the hierarchy check and made sure the wizards were listed correctly in their
corresponding categories in the second tab. I also ensured all templates were
found and shown in the first tab. :)

Bug.WithStack:
The new extension wizard available in M8 does not display wizard categories anymore and enforces a 1:1 mapping between wizards and extensions. The latter is a real problem since we have important features targetting Eclipse 3.0 that are relying on an 1:n mapping.
E.g. We use implemented a category to host menu contribution wizards to guide the user in generating/modifing many menu/action related extension points
A possible solution would be to list custom categories at the top of the extensions list and display their associated wizards in the bottom left pane upon selection. Here is how I see things moving:
1) Templates are mapped 1->1 with extension points. This mapping is programmatically available (via ITemplateSection.getUsedExtensionPoint()), but not in the template declaration in plugin.xml. This mapping should be added there.
2) By declaring the mapping in 1), we should drop 'contributingId' in extension wizard extension point because it wrongly implies that this wizard can contribute only one extension. Instead, we should change the behaviour of the attribute 'template' from 'boolean' (is/is not a template) to string (template id). This way, one can either define 'class' attribute (we will use it as a wizard), or 'template' attribute. In the later case, the value would be the ID of the template registered elsewhere using the 'templates' extension point. By looking up the template, we will be able to get the contributingId from it, so the current code will work normally.
3) The current page is very good and useful for most of the users. I would not complicate the dialog any further by adding categories etc. Right now, the selector is extension point, for which we check if there are templates with the matching contributing id. I propose that we add a tabbed folder to the wizard, with the first tab being the current content, and the second one being custom wizards. Alternatively, we can have a tree view and with two root nodes corresponding to the two tabs. However, in this particular case I would like to make the most common case the default i.e. to prevent adding mouse clicks to get to the most common state. I agree with this proposal.
The number of extension-points being high, the use of a single tree to host both 1-1 and custom wizards would make it hard to discover the latter. Consequently, my vote goes for a separate tab on the wizard. This will be much easier to discover for beginners; the primary audience of these wizards.
OK, so what is left is to define the content of the second tab and to shoose the tab captions.
I propose that we reuse the existing infrastructure for the category tree/wizards/description that was there before. The functionality exists already so we just need to tap into it and place it in a second tab.
The wizards to use should be all the extensions that plug-in into 'newExtension' extension point that have a 'class' attribute defined. Those with the 'template' attribute used should be filtered out.
The tabs should be something like:
[Extension Points and Templates] [Custom Wizards]
The first tab seems long - I am open to shorter alternatives. Using a filtered version of the "old" wizard for the second tab look ok to me.
I am not sure "custom" is appropriate for the second tab. I propose we name the tabs in a way that highlite the 1:*, or task oriented, nature of "custom" wizards. i.e. 1:1 wizard should probably appear on the first tab, even though they are "custom".
Something like: [Extension Points][Extension Tasks] I would rather keep all the 'custom' wizards on the second tab. These are the wizards that have the 'class' attribute defined. The first tab should be reserved for extension points (just creating an empty one possibly with required attributes set to something as we do today), and templates i.e. wizards that have the 'template' attribute set instead of the 'class'. The reason for this special status of templates is that they have the inherent 1- >1 mapping (via the newly added 'contributingId' attribute). In contrast, wizards that contribute a class don't have this clear mapping (I would like to remove 'contributingId' attribute from the 'newExtension' extention point). The implementation is now in HEAD but it changed somewhat. Allow me to explain:
Point 1) and 2) has been implemented. PDE UI is fully switch to it. All the templates are now required to declared 'contributingId' attribute. The same attribute is dropped from 'newExtension' extension point.
I also implemented the tabs, but they work in a different way:
The first tab is called 'Extension Points'. It focuses on extension points (as today) and also hooks wizards that are declared as templates (regardless of categories).
The second tab is called 'Extension Wizards'. It is simply offered as a category+wizard view of the same data. It shows the familiar three-pane layout with categories, wizards and description. All the registered wizards are shown here (including template wizards). Therefore, the two tabs simply show extension point-centric and wizard-centric view of the same content. Of course, wizards that are not template-based are now shown in the 'Extension Points' tab because 1->1 mapping could not be established between the points and wizards.
Mostly done.
I took the occasion to replace composites in the three-pane tab with sash forms so that the ratios can be individually resized.
Cherie, please do some sanity tests and look for little glitches. Please create some dummy wizards with elaborate category hieararchy (several levels) and test that:
1) Templates several levels deep in the hierarchy are all found and shown in the first tab 2) All the wizards are properly show up in the second tab under their corresponding categories 3) The description in the wizard makes sense for all the selections in all the tabs 4) Wizard buttons properly enable/disable based on the selection in the tabs. Hi Dejan,
I did some sanity testing it was looking good! :)
One minor thing I noticed is if I can be in the "Extension Points" tab and select a template as usual (i.e. MPE). Then change my mind and go to "Extension Wizards" but not select a category or custom wizard. The "Next" button is still enabled because the next page is still set for the MPE properties. I change the code just now such that switching between tabs will not bring over the previous selection.
The last thing I want to double check is to make sure we're displaying templates that are several levels deep in the hierarchy. Problem here is that I'm not sure what is meant by 'several levels deep in the hierarchy'. Could someone elaborate? :)
Thanks!
'Several levels' scenario as follows:
1) A number of templates is registered with a category c1/c2/c3 2) The second page (category-based) should show the template wizards when c3 is selected in the left pane 3) The first page should show the templates declared under c3 when the matching extension point is selected Ran the hierarchy check and made sure the wizards were listed correctly in their corresponding categories in the second tab. I also ensured all templates were found and shown in the first tab. :)
Three cheers for a great wizard :)

Bug.Summery: [Refactoring] should reject tabs in new names

Lines.Line: 1. In a CDT editor, create and save a line containing a tab:
3. Select some element Foo and invoke rename refactoring on it.
4. Paste the copy buffer into the new name field.
The name is considered acceptable, and no warning is produced.

Bug.WithStack:
Using 2.0.0.200404160300 On Windows
1. In a CDT editor, create and save a line containing a tab: // hello there 2. Select and copy "hello there". 3. Select some element Foo and invoke rename refactoring on it. 4. Paste the copy buffer into the new name field. The name is considered acceptable, and no warning is produced.
EXPECTED: Reject names containing tabs
Note: spaces in or around the new name are correctly detected and rejected with the error message "Class name has blanks" (OK button is disabled)
Leading or trailing tabs (versus embedded tabs) are correctly detected and rejected with the same error message "Class name has blanks".
JDT Rename-Refactoring handles tabs correctly.
(Newline and CarriageReturn appear well-behaved in similar testing. I'll hold off on the handling of other harder-to-type control characters for now.) ditto my previous comment about using an IScanner ... Fixed in HEAD. Now an identifier name should be a legal identifier (starts with a letter or '_' and continutes with a letter, digit or '_') and a valid identifier (not a keyword or a reserved word according to the scanner ) Verified in 2.0.0.200404280300 Thanks Hoda
Bug.WithOutStack:
Using 2.0.0.200404160300 On Windows
1. In a CDT editor, create and save a line containing a tab: // hello there 2. Select and copy "hello there". 3. Select some element Foo and invoke rename refactoring on it. 4. Paste the copy buffer into the new name field. The name is considered acceptable, and no warning is produced.
EXPECTED: Reject names containing tabs
Note: spaces in or around the new name are correctly detected and rejected with the error message "Class name has blanks" (OK button is disabled)
Leading or trailing tabs (versus embedded tabs) are correctly detected and rejected with the same error message "Class name has blanks".
JDT Rename-Refactoring handles tabs correctly.
(Newline and CarriageReturn appear well-behaved in similar testing. I'll hold off on the handling of other harder-to-type control characters for now.) ditto my previous comment about using an IScanner ... Fixed in HEAD. Bug.Summery: cannot specify value except IE as "Application to record"

Lines.Line: 2- open combo box for "Application to Record"

Bug.WithStack:
OS: <AIX 5.2> Language: <Japanese locale:Ja_JP.IBM-943> Build level: <3.0-aix-motif(200404131323)> JDK version: IBM JDK 1.4.2 Beta testcase: Hyades 3.0 Recorder and Testgen NLS Input
Summary: DBCS: cannot specify application except IE as "Application to record" value
Steps to recreate problem: 1- Window->Preference->Test->Http Proxy Recorder 2- open combo box for "Application to Record"
Error: Although eclipse runs on AIX, only Internet Explorer is available as value of "Application to Record". There are not Mozilla or Netscape.
Expected Result: "Mozilla" or "Netscape" should be available as value of "Application to Record", because AIX does not have Internet Explorer. Created attachment 9707 screenshot This bug also occurs on build 20040419-0915(wswb-I20040413-200404191247) for platform windows2003 standand edtion, RHEL WS 3.0 -GTK, suse 9 beta3. Louis Cai This is not a DBCS-specific issue.
Mozilla/Netscape are not supported at this time and will not be added to applications for 3.0. You can always set application to "None" and launch and configure that browser to point to a socks=localhost:1080 proxy automatically.
For 3.0, added a "supportedOS" to the schema for application adapters. From an end-user perspective, applications will not be selectable for unsupported operating systems. Thus, "Internet Explorer" will not be selectable from non- Windows systems.
Changing resolution to LATER. Mozilla adapter will be addressed post-3.0. No current plans for Netscape, but may be added if transition from Mozilla is minimal. (Addendum) Fixed a UI bug that was setting preference to IE even if None was selected.
3.0_20040428_1802 I confirmed that only "None" was displayed in Preference->Test->Http Proxy Recorder setting, on I20040506 build. So, I close this bug. Thanks. house keeping LATER/REMIND bugs are being automatically reopened as P5 because the LATER and REMIND resolutions are deprecated. As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. Since this defect is more than 2 years old, it may be no longer relevant. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this defect is resolved as WONTFIX. If this defect is still relevant and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open. closed

Bug.Summery: [Javadoc] [Themes] API docs
Bug.WithStack:
The api docs for the themes package seems mostly complete. I think that only the following two bits are needed:
- class doc for ITheme - package.html
My impression at this point is that I understand the purpose of the themes package, but I'm not sure where to begin using it. Changes in HEAD.
The thing with themes is, most users will never have need to access them directly. The workbench pushes the contents of the currently active theme into the JFace registries so people can (continue to) use those registries. Using themes directly is an advanced topic that deserves an article or somesuch treatment on the website. Closing.

My impression at this point is that I understand the purpose of the themes package, but I'm not sure where to begin using it. Changes in HEAD.
The thing with themes is, most users will never have need to access them directly. The workbench pushes the contents of the currently active theme into the JFace registries so people can (continue to) use those registries. Using themes directly is an advanced topic that deserves an article or somesuch treatment on the website. Closing.

Bug.Summery: Negative time value in sequence diagram

Lines.Line: - reassign that bug to another team? and which one?
- take this case into account, making the hypothesis that the last known and
earlier time is the good one?
- check it again with the latest agent build?
For the moment, I leave it as assigned to dguilbaud.
The sample I was using runs forever, and I have to explicitly terminate it.
Would this cause part of what you're seeing?
So, it brings us to follow the second solution:
- take this case into account, making the hypothesis that the last known and
earlier time is the good one
Fixed in HEAD stream for Hyades 3.0 M9
Closing bugs that were previously verified.

Bug.WithStack:
Suse 8.2 - Motif Hyades 3.0_20040419_0915
I was testing the hot spots in the sequence diagram when I found some negative values for the times. I also found some zeros. I got this on my first try, so it shouldn't be too difficult. I believe I was profiling a simple hello world application with all filters turned off.
Screenshot to follow.. Created attachment 9708 screenshot Dominique, can you please check and see if this can be fixed in M9. Could you please provide us with the trace files Created attachment 9784 trace file
Import this trace file in the profiling monitor (make sure you include execution flow). The incorrect agent label is a known defect. Open the agent with thread interactions. There should be only one block on the left side, click on it, and see the negative value. This fragment set is incomplete: no threadEnd is in and would correspond to the threadStart fragment that is near the beginning. Also the last fragment is a methodEntry with a stackDepth of 3, like if something was going wrong in the application being profiled during this call. An important information here is that all the filters are turned off: java.lang.String and any other JRE classes are tracked. Should we: - reassign that bug to another team? and which one? - take this case into account, making the hypothesis that the last known and earlier time is the good one? - check it again with the latest agent build? For the moment, I leave it as assigned to dguilbaud. The sample I was using runs forever, and I have to explicitly terminate it. Would this cause part of what you're seeing? Thanks for your update. So, it brings us to follow the second solution: - take this case into account, making the hypothesis that the last known and earlier time is the good one M10 target ok. Fixed in HEAD stream for Hyades 3.0 M9 Verified. Can't reproduce the problem. Closing bugs that were previously verified.

Bug.Summery: Some plug-ins are not filtered as binary
Bug.WithStack:
Using build I20040420, some binary imported plug-ins are not filtered using the 'binary plug-in' filter in Package Explorer:
org.eclipse.osgi org.eclipse.osgi.services org.eclipse.osgi.util
None of these plug-ins have plugin.xml (they are pure bundles), so that may be the reason. Fixed. Happy, pappy? :-) I can now resume normal activities.

However deleting them did not help Since I already have a bug for the first problem (see bug 59430), I forwarding this to core to handle the deletion problem. Michael, can you explain what "the deletion problem" is? If a project is deleted, the rules factory for the project is not removed. If the project is recreated, it would use the old rule factory. This is not as serious as the CVS part of this bug (which I have fixed) so it is not really critical anymore. It's really just a cleanup issue. Fixed. Rule factories are now discarded after project delete, close, and move. *** Bug 68812 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Bug.Summery: [Progress] autobuild job not in progress view initially

Lines.Line: - I started up this build on an existing workspace.
- When it started the status bar told me that it was "Building Workspace".
- I saw a cool "i" icon so I clicked on it and it brought up the progress view.
- I used the drop-down menu to "show verbose"
- oh, there is the build operation!
- build operation stayed in the progress view
John is this a system job?
It's not a system job. Note that after toggling verbose on and then off again,
it looked fine. I think this is a case of a job that starts running before the
UI has had a chance to hook its progress provider. See also bug 57537.
We are now suspending the job manager while the UI starts up. I am going to
leave this open just in case we still get it but I beleive it is fixed in

Bug.WithStack:
build i0420-0800
- I started up this build on an existing workspace. - When it started the status bar told me that it was "Building Workspace". - I saw a cool "i" icon so I clicked on it and it brought up the progress view. - progress view was empty - I used the drop-down menu to "show verbose" - oh, there is the build operation! - turned off verbose mode - build operation stayed in the progress view John is this a system job? It's not a system job. Note that after toggling verbose on and then off again, it looked fine. I think this is a case of a job that starts running before the UI has had a chance to hook its progress provider. See also bug 57537. We are now suspending the job manager while the UI starts up. I am going to leave this open just in case we still get it but I beleive it is fixed in build >20045029 Closing. Marking closed
Bug.WithOutStack:
build i0420-0800
- I started up this build on an existing workspace. - When it started the status bar told me that it was "Building Workspace". - I saw a cool "i" icon so I clicked on it and it brought up the progress view. - progress view was empty - I used the drop-down menu to "show verbose" - oh, there is the build operation! - turned off verbose mode - build operation stayed in the progress view John is this a system job? It's not a system job. Note that after toggling verbose on and then off again, it looked fine. I think this is a case of a job that starts running before the UI has had a chance to hook its progress provider. See also bug 57537. We are now suspending the job manager while the UI starts up. I am going to leave this open just in case we still get it but I beleive it is fixed in build >20045029 Closing. Marking closed

Bug.Summery: Possibility to share compiler preferences for a shared project
Bug.WithStack:
Currently the compiler settings (Compliance, Problems, Style) are configured per workspace and may be customized for individual projects. But this is still stored inside workspace (under the .metadata area).
A functionality that is missing is sharing these settings per-project with other team members. Most probably that would mean having an additional dot-file (e.g. .compilersettings, something containing similar information like .jprefs files do) inside the project and sharing it transparently through VCS.
In my opinion and experience, the compiler settings are part of project properties rather than individual customization. Any points showing that I am mistaken are also welcome. This is something we had in mind since day one, but were reluctant to add yet another artifact. We want to convert in a near future to using new shareable preference support from the platform (on per project basis).
Time permitting. *** Bug 59809 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 59808 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 59928 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Investigating feasability within M9, if unable then will be deferred post 3.0. Deferring as platform code hasn't fully stabilized yet. Migration is finished, but too risky for 3.0. We will though release it into 1.5 branch, and it will be available in the Cheetah update.
Frederic - pls also attach your changes to this defect as a patch. Created attachment 10314 Patch implementing new preferences API for jdt-core.
This patch is available for build I200405050200. I will refresh it when necessary... Applying it will result to move project jdt-core preferences from file <workspace>/.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.core.resources\.projects\<project>\org.eclipse.jdt.core\.jprefs directory to file <workspace>/<project>/.settings/org.eclipse.jdt.core.prefs Note that this patch also requires a patch for test class OptionTests in project org.eclipse.jdt.core.tests.model. I will attache a patch in next comment...
If you try to use this patch, please let me know any trouble you get with it, thx Created attachment 10315 Patch for jdt.core.tests.model project
Here's the patch to avoid trouble with OptionTests class in org.eclipse.jdt.core.tests.model project... Note that this code should be released in 1.5 code stream by the end of this week and so will be available in next "official" Cheetah version (Cheetah 05).
Fixed and released in JDK_1_5 branch (since v_150_0506).
Should have been tagged as fixed. Fixed. *** Bug 54814 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 69103 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Verified in I200409230100.

Bug.Summery: DBCS: RAServer fail to start by inappropriate LIBPATH

Lines.Line: 2- accoding to getting-started.txt in zip file, set RASERVER_HOME, LIBPATH and

Bug.WithStack:
OS: <AIX 5.2> Language: <Japanese locale:Ja_JP.IBM-943> Build level: <3.0-aix-motif(200404131323)> JDK version: IBM JDK 1.4.2 Beta
Summary: DBCS: RAServer fail to start by inappropriate LIBPATH
Steps to recreate problem: 1- unzip eclipse-install-dir/hyades/aix_ppc.zip to $HOME/raserver 2- accoding to getting-started.txt in zip file, set RASERVER_HOME, LIBPATH and PATH like following: #export RASERVER_HOME=$HOME/raserver #export LIBPATH=$LIBPATH:$RASERVER_HOME/lib #export PATH=$PATH:$RASERVER_HOME/bin 3- execute $RASERVER_HOME/bin/SetConfig.sh 4- execute $RASERVER_HOME/bin/RAServer
Error: RAServer outputs following error message:
Unable to dlopen libjava.a: No such file or directory JVMCI114: Cannot obtain system-specific information Cannot bind to client handling socket 4 using port 10002. Make sure the port is free and no other RAC is using the same port.
Then, RAServer continue to run, but this RAServer is not available from eclipse functions, such as Http Proxy Recorder.
Expected Result: After adding JRE-install-dir/bin and JRE-install-dir/bin/classic to LIBPATH like following, RAServer could be invoked correctly. #export LIBPATH=$LIBPATH:/path/to/jre/bin:/path/to/jre/bin/classic
So, getting-started.txt should be updated to add these paths to LIBPATH. Samson, Yet another regression caused by the file transfer stuff. Can you work with the team to get this cleaned up ASAP. Please assign the bug to the correct component, in this case Data Collection and Control. There were actually 2 problems described in this bug: 1. Cannot create a JVM for file transfer service 2. Cannot handle client request because port 10002 is busy
Problem #1 should already be fixed in such a way that if a JVM cannot be created, the data collection engine will keep on running with the file transfer feature disabled. This should not crash the data collection engine.
Problem #2 can be resolved by making sure port 10002 is free before starting the data collection engine. Nothing should show up when running the command "netstat -a | grep 10002".
After confirming "netstat -a |grep 10002" results did not show anything, I tried invoking RAServer again with LIBPATH=$RASERVER_HOME/lib (not contain /path/to/jre/bin and /path/to/jre/bin/classic). As a result, RAServer outputted only Problem #1 error message, and became available from Http Proxy Recorder.
Thank you for explanations and I will close this bug.
Bug.WithOutStack:
OS: <AIX 5.2> Language: <Japanese locale:Ja_JP.IBM-943> Build level: <3.0-aix-motif(200404131323)> JDK version: IBM JDK 1.4.2 Beta

Expected Result: After adding JRE-install-dir/bin and JRE-install-dir/bin/classic to LIBPATH like following, RAServer could be invoked correctly. #export LIBPATH=$LIBPATH:/path/to/jre/bin:/path/to/jre/bin/classic
So, getting-started.txt should be updated to add these paths to LIBPATH. Samson, Yet another regression caused by the file transfer stuff. Can you work with the team to get this cleaned up ASAP. Please assign the bug to the correct component, in this case Data Collection and Control. There were actually 2 problems described in this bug: 1. Cannot create a JVM for file transfer service 2. Cannot handle client request because port 10002 is busy
Problem #1 should already be fixed in such a way that if a JVM cannot be created, the data collection engine will keep on running with the file transfer feature disabled. This should not crash the data collection engine.

After confirming "netstat -a |grep 10002" results did not show anything, I tried invoking RAServer again with LIBPATH=$RASERVER_HOME/lib (not contain /path/to/jre/bin and /path/to/jre/bin/classic). Bug.Summery: Plug-in manifest editor does not display icons when using "%" attribute value
Bug.WithStack:
Example: On the Extensions tab in the Plug-in Manifest editor, extensions to org.eclipse.ui.views are displayed with an icon according to the value of the "icon" attribute of the corresponding element.
But an "indirect" value is used for the attribute, e.g. "%MyView.icon", no icon is displayed (though this works in the application and the manifest editor expands for example the view name this way).
Note: In Eclipse3.0M8 a default icon is shown in the editor, but in E2.x this actually caused an exception and impossibility to use the Extensions tab in the manifest editor. The "icon" attribute is declared in the schema to be of type "Resource", not "String". So its value is not meant to be translated and does not get translated by PDE at dev time. It is a path to the resource, not a translatable attribute. Thanks for explanation. I didn't realize that translations may be applied to "String" attributes only, also because it worked for icons at run-time with no problems.
Bug.WithOutStack:

But an "indirect" value is used for the attribute, e.g. "%MyView.icon", no icon is displayed (though this works in the application and the manifest editor expands for example the view name this way).

It is a path to the resource, not a translatable attribute. Thanks for explanation. I didn't realize that translations may be applied to "String" attributes only, also because it worked for icons at run-time with no problems.

Bug.Summery: API contributions of org.eclipse.core.runtime.jobs.InternalJob

Lines.Line: 1) I can add methods to without breaking clients
2) Has access to non-public internal implementation classes and methods
This API has been cleaned up. All public and protected methods are subclassed
and spec'd in the API subclass. All other members have been made package or

Bug.WithStack:
The org.eclipse.core.runtime.jobs.InternalJob class is the internal superclass of the API class Job.
InternalJob currently declares public and protected fields and methods. This is a problem, because those will be inherited by the API class and be almost indistinguisable from API fields and methods.
If the intent is for a member to be API, it needs to be declared and spec'd on the API class. If it's not supposed to be API, it needs to be private or package-private. Good catch on the fields - those should be package-private. All of the protected methods are overridden and fully spec'd in the API subclass, Job. Presumably this is ok? This is the same convention we have followed in, for example, InternalBuilder and IncrementalProjectBuilder. No problem with protected methods overridden and fully spec'd in the API subclass. (Aside: The general pattern of having a internal superclass is error prone, however, because the developer must be careful to not add public and protected members.) Agree this is error-prone. This is the only mechanism I know for creating an API that:
1) I can add methods to without breaking clients 2) Has access to non-public internal implementation classes and methods This API has been cleaned up. All public and protected methods are subclassed and spec'd in the API subclass. All other members have been made package or private visibility.
Bug.WithOutStack:
The org.eclipse.core.runtime.jobs.InternalJob class is the internal superclass of the API class Job.
InternalJob currently declares public and protected fields and methods. This is a problem, because those will be inherited by the API class and be almost indistinguisable from API fields and methods.
If the intent is for a member to be API, it needs to be declared and spec'd on the API class. If it's not supposed to be API, it needs to be private or package-private. Good catch on the fields - those should be package-private. All of the protected methods are overridden and fully spec'd in the API subclass, Job. Presumably this is ok? This is the same convention we have followed in, for example, InternalBuilder and IncrementalProjectBuilder. No problem with protected methods overridden and fully spec'd in the API subclass. (Aside: The general pattern of having a internal superclass is error prone, however, because the developer must be careful to not add public and protected members.) Agree this is error-prone. This is the only mechanism I know for creating an API that:
1) I can add methods to without breaking clients 2) Has access to non-public internal implementation classes and methods This API has been cleaned up. All public and protected methods are subclassed and spec'd in the API subclass. All other members have been made package or private visibility.
