"VM Periodic Task Thread" prio=10 tid=0x00a111a0 nid=0xdfc waiting on condition "Suspend Checker Thread" prio=10 tid=0x009fb960 nid=0xab8 runnable There are two different stack traces here, and they are both very busy. Were they taken with a significant gap between them? Were they taken near the beginning of the minute or near the end? It is hard to tell where the time is going.
I am CC'ing team guys because the syncExec during CVS UI plugin startup scares me (the first stack trace). It isn't deadlocking here but it has great deadlock potential.
The second stack dump, where the main thread is blocked on the workspace lock, is not surprising. That lock is held for the duration of each core API call (in this case File.create(). As soon as the create() method exits, the other thread should be able to proceed. This lock isn't held for long periods. If autobuild was running, I would expect the build to have been canceled and restarted here. Only the last dump is valid. The first dump has been done some time before (wasn't aware that I posted two dumps - sorry).
FYI: The syncExec has been removed from the CVS UI plugin. Closing. Nothing appears to be wrong in the stack dump. The build is running, and will eventually interrupt if someone has changed the workspace.
Bug.WithOutStack:
I20040420
I am not sure whether this is a problem but at least it looks like one: I opened a text search match while building the workspace. The main thread was frozen for almost a minute (see thread dump below). I don't understand why the job manager waits since the scheduling rule for creating markers is null.

org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.PlatformActivator$1.run(PlatformActivator.java:280) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:240) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:117) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39) at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25) at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:324) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:267) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:699) at Were they taken with a significant gap between them? Were they taken near the beginning of the minute or near the end? It is hard to tell where the time is going.
I am CC'ing team guys because the syncExec during CVS UI plugin startup scares me (the first stack trace). It isn't deadlocking here but it has great deadlock potential.
The second stack dump, where the main thread is blocked on the workspace lock, is not surprising. That lock is held for the duration of each core API call (in this case File.create(). As soon as the create() method exits, the other thread should be able to proceed. This lock isn't held for long periods. If autobuild was running, I would expect the build to have been canceled and restarted here. Only the last dump is valid. The first dump has been done some time before (wasn't aware that I posted two dumps - sorry).
FYI: The syncExec has been removed from the CVS UI plugin. Closing. Nothing appears to be wrong in the stack dump. The build is running, and will eventually interrupt if someone has changed the workspace.

Bug.Summery: Remove the final modifier from the alignment action
Bug.WithStack:
AlignmentAction from GEF explicitly requires that all elements are in the same container. In our application we have table where each cell is a separate container but we still allow to select elements in different cells and align them together (i.e. if all elements belong to cells from the same row we allow to align top, bottom and middle, if all elements are in cells that are in the same column we allow left, right and center alignment)
As a result it will be enough to overwrite the getOperationSet method. Sorry, API changes aren't permitted at this time. LATER and REMIND resolutions will be going away with the upgrade of Bugzilla to the latest Bugzilla 3.4. They are no longer part of the default Bugzilla installation. See http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/eclipse.org-committers/msg00778.html for the announcement.
As a result RESOLVED + REMIND OR LATER will be changed to RESOLVED + WONTFIX
This unfortunately also means I need to REOPEN and then RESOLVE as WONTFIX
Sorry for the inconvenience. LATER and REMIND resolutions will be going away with the upgrade of Bugzilla to the latest Bugzilla 3.4. They are no longer part of the default Bugzilla installation. See http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/eclipse.org-committers/msg00778.html for the announcement.
As a result RESOLVED + REMIND OR LATER will be changed to RESOLVED + WONTFIX
This unfortunately also means I need to REOPEN and then RESOLVE as WONTFIX
Sorry for the inconvenience.

Bug.Summery: ctrl-arrow skips keywords

Lines.Line: - ctrl-rightArrow to stop before the "C" in children
- ctrl-leftArrow to take me to column 13 (befor the "I" in initialize)
Note that the "home" key puts the cursor where I want it but with my programming
style I tend to use ctrl-arrow more. (especially since I got a new keyboard with

Bug.WithStack:
build i0420-0800
I've noticed in the past couple of builds that the ctrl-arrow behaviour seems to have changed. I wasn't sure what it was but now I think that I've determined what the cause of my confusion is...ctrl-arrow seems to ignore Java keywords.
I have the prefs for Smart Cursor Positioning Line Start/End and Java Names both turned on.
Consider the following line: this(null, null);
If the cursor is positioned before the first bracket and I hit ctrl-leftArrow, the cursor is moved to line position 1 rather than just before the "t".
I would prefer it to move to the beginning of the text, even though its a keyword. Actually its not only with keywords that the behaviour is unexpected. Consider the following example:
if (!initialized) initializeChildren();
If you position the cursor in column 1 of the second line and hit ctrl-rightArrow, it goes to column 31. (just before the first bracket)
Then you hit ctrl-leftArrow and it goes to column 23 (before the "C" in children).
Then you hit ctrl-leftArrow and it goes to column 1.
The behaviour is not symetrical. (not sure if that's the right word to use here)
I would expect: - ctrl-rightArrow to stop before the "C" in children - ctrl-leftArrow to take me to column 13 (befor the "I" in initialize) Note that the "home" key puts the cursor where I want it but with my programming style I tend to use ctrl-arrow more. (especially since I got a new keyboard with home/end in bizarre places)
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 37785 ***

build i0420-0800

Consider the following line: this(null, null);
If the cursor is positioned before the first bracket and I hit ctrl-leftArrow, the cursor is moved to line position 1 rather than just before the "t".
I would prefer it to move to the beginning of the text, even though its a keyword. Actually its not only with keywords that the behaviour is unexpected. Consider the following example:

If you position the cursor in column 1 of the second line and hit ctrl-rightArrow, it goes to column 31. (just before the first bracket)
Then you hit ctrl-leftArrow and it goes to column 23 (before the "C" in children).
Then you hit ctrl-leftArrow and it goes to column 1.
The behaviour is not symetrical. (not sure if that's the right word to use here)
I would expect: - ctrl-rightArrow to stop before the "C" in children - ctrl-leftArrow to take me to column 13 (befor the "I" in initialize) Note that the "home" key puts the cursor where I want it but with my programming style I tend to use ctrl-arrow more. Bug.Summery: Ongoing Search disables hovers for whole workbench

Lines.Line: 1. start a search that has many matches (or takes long)
2. hover over icons in Search view, or main tool bar or in editor

Bug.WithStack:
I20040420
1. start a search that has many matches (or takes long) 2. hover over icons in Search view, or main tool bar or in editor
==> no hovers
Stop search or wait until finished ==> hovers are back That is not correct. You do get hovers, but it seems that the load we're putting on the system seems to interfere with the hovers, making them unreliable. Some more observations:
1) Tree hovers (for example, the package explorer) work when using the tree search view; the editor hovers don't work anymore. 2) The flat list view makes stuff really slow. I guess we're just paying the price for updating the table. Note that we still get the tree hovers, they're just sluggish. I agree that it is a question of how much load is on my system. Search - compared to other background jobs - heavily runs in the UI.
I fixed the immediate problem by introducing some architecture that sleeps() at times. Shouldn't this be a problems solved by lower levels. How about running a job in a low priority thread? At least best effort? If search is doing lots of work in the UI thread, there is not much we can do about it in the platform. We currently ensure that all background jobs run in a thread with priority lower than the UI thread, but even thread priorities are not honored by all VMs (it is specified as a hint). Apart from doing less work in the UI thread, or batching up chunks of work rather than flooding with many (a)syncExecs, I don't know what to suggest. Fair enough.

I20040420
1. start a search that has many matches (or takes long) 2. hover over icons in Search view, or main tool bar or in editor
==> no hovers
Stop search or wait until finished ==> hovers are back That is not correct. You do get hovers, but it seems that the load we're putting on the system seems to interfere with the hovers, making them unreliable. Some more observations:
1) Tree hovers (for example, the package explorer) work when using the tree search view; the editor hovers don't work anymore. 2) The flat list view makes stuff really slow. I guess we're just paying the price for updating the table. Note that we still get the tree hovers, they're just sluggish. I agree that it is a question of how much load is on my system. Search - compared to other background jobs - heavily runs in the UI.
I fixed the immediate problem by introducing some architecture that sleeps() at times. Shouldn't this be a problems solved by lower levels. How about running a job in a low priority thread? Apart from doing less work in the UI thread, or batching up chunks of work rather than flooding with many (a)syncExecs, I don't know what to suggest. Fair enough.

Bug.Summery: [ViewMgmt] Search view flickers extremely while updating
Bug.WithStack:
I20040420
When searching in background with many matches the italic title flickers. Also, when having many matches that get grouped into one element this element flickers. parts of this PR are probably Platform UI (e.g. flickering when using setTitle).
Do you have a particular search that shows the problem? text search which has lots of matches and takes quite long.
e.g. search for * in workspace ;-) I reduced the frequency of setTitle() calls, but we're still getting some flickering. Note that the whole tab flickers, even though the part of the title string that is shown in the tab proper (i.e. "Search") never changes.
Moving to Platform-UI. Just to note that this is a critical bug for search. Should optimize out unnecessary updates. This should probably be done in the workbench, rather than relying on the presentation to be smart.
Please consider for M9.

EXPECTED #2: The warning should match the New Class Wizard:
"Class name is discouraged. Class name starts with lower case"

"Class name is not valid. Class name has blanks"

Bug.Summery: [ViewMgmt] Closing a view in a tabgroup should bring the LRU tab to top
Bug.WithStack:
Steps to reproduce:
Have three views in a tabbed pane - e.g. Problems, Search and Progress, in this order. When in Problems, switch to the Progress view and close it.
In E2.1 you end up back in the Problems view, which is correct. In E3.0M8 you end up in the Search view, which is not so convenient and furthermore may activate this view as it may have been unused before. MRU behaviour is important. See also bug 56603.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 56603 ***
Bug.WithOutStack:

Bug.Summery: Externalize strings support for plug manifest files
Bug.WithStack:
Maybe I've overlooked it... but I don't see a nice "Externalize Strings..." wizard for the plugin.xml file, i.e., it has to be done by hand. A wizard that examined the strings in plugin.xml and proposed a dialog similar to the *.java "Externalize Strings..." dialog would be very helpful.
There are also performance advantages to the plugin.properties files versus standalone / Message bundle that the current wizard generates, since plugin.properties is cached in the .registry file. For extra credit, enhance the existing Externalize Strings wizard to offer the option of retrieving strings from the plug-in's strings.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 51336 ***

The attached example shows 2 attempts to create a dynamic cascading menu: 1) SampleAction implements IWorkbenchWindowPulldownDelegate2 - creates a menu but once created is never inquiried about being updated
2) SampleAction2 implements IWorkbenchWindowPulldownDelegate2 - creates a menu and fills it by delegating to a ContributionItem - this is basically the same as the first
org.eclipse.jface.action.MenuManager.update(boolean force, boolean recursive) is invoked when the Menu is about to show but never delegates to actions contributed from an actionSets.
Is there a mechanism to do this? Created attachment 9712 Example which creates cascading menu via actionSets ext point See how Debug's AbstractLaunchHistoryAction.initMenu does it. Basically you need to hook a menu listener on the menu, and can then do whatever changes you want there, including disposing all old items.
Note that they only recreate the menu when necessary, when the launch history has actually changed.
This is not ideal. I'm leaving this PR open to address the difficulty with dynamic menus post 3.0.
AbstractLaunchHistoryAction seems to also keep track of any previously created menu and dispose it when creating a new one. Not sure if this is necessary to prevent leaks. Darin?
This is the memory I have. We added this as we were leaking the menus that we had created. Assigning to component owner PW

Bug.Summery: Please add "Show/Hide Inner Classes" to Hierarchy View [type hierarchy]
Bug.WithStack:
I20040413
- Select a package, that has a bunch of inner classes, in the Package Explorer. (I selected org.eclipse.swt.examples.controlexample - it's in the org.eclipse.swt.examples project).
- Choose "Open Type Hierarchy" (or F4).
- After the Hierarchy View opens, you will notice that the "meat" of what you want to look at is somewhat obscured. (In my case, there are really only two hierarchies in this package that are interesting: ControlExample, and Tab). It would be nice if I could choose to hide the inner class hierarchies with an easy-to-access tool button on the Hierarchy View's toolbar.
(Also would be nice if the inner class hierarchies could come up collapsed in the tree, instead of expanded).
In SWT, we tend to have a lot of listeners, and we almost never want to see them as a class in their own right, because they are only interesting in the context of the class that they are defined in. (So it makes more sense to just go see them in the compilation unit of the defining class).
I suspect that it is more important to allow hiding of anonymous inner classes than named ones. The anonymous ones just aren't very interesting by themselves. At the very least, please don't expand the tree to show inner classes - particularly anonymous ones. I just said "Browse Hierarchy" on the org.eclipse.swt project, and there are bunches of uninteresting anonymous inner classes taking up valuable tree view real estate. :) Thanks. unfortunatly the filter feature for the hierarchy didn't make it for M9
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 40630 ***

Bug.Summery: Unable to include an external folder with class files to project classpath
Bug.WithStack:
Documentation to IClasspathEntry ( http://help.eclipse.org/help21/topic/org.eclipse.jdt.doc.isv/reference/api/org/e clipse/jdt/core/IClasspathEntry.html ) mentions possibility to use a folder with class files external to the workspace.
But this does not work. The Build Path configuration dialog allows only picking folders from workspace, but I have tried adding entry
<classpathentry kind="lib" path="/C:/test/classes"/>
directly to .classpath file in my project. The build path was considered OK, but the classes from the folder were not available on the project classpath. The interesting thing is, that when I specified a non-existing folder, I got a build path error and the project did not compile at all.
Same behavior observed in both E2.1 and E3.0M8.
Note: "Setting the Java build path" ( http://help.eclipse.org/help21/topic/org.eclipse.jdt.doc.isv/guide/jdt_api_class path.htm ) mentions that the class file folder should be inside the workspace only, which is a conflict with the documentation mentioned above. You should not edit the .classpath yourself. Go to the project properties>Java Build Path>Libraries>Add Class Folder>Create New Folder...>Advanced>
In the folder name, you put the name you want to see in the project. You check "Link to folder on the file system" and then you browse to the directory you want.
Click OK until you close the dialog. This should work. I see, so I must link the external folder into the workspace.
However that means that the documentation in IClasspathEntry is not right. I found this problem because I actually did this thing programatically (which now turns out to require two steps - linking the folder and then adding it to the classpath).
And second point is that the build path processor in fact considers the external folders somehow - as I wrote, it was checking whether the folder exists or not and did not produce any warning about that it is not supported (or that it is not a jar file).
And sorry for touching the .classpath file directly, that was just for testing :-)
Jerome - pls make change to spec to clarify this situation. Clarified the spec to say that a binary folder must be internal to the workspace, or that it must be first linked using IFolder#createLink(...) if it is external. *** Bug 59987 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Verified in 200405180816. Clarifications have been added inside javaCore.newLibraryFolder(...).
Bug.WithOutStack:
Documentation to IClasspathEntry ( http://help.eclipse.org/help21/topic/org.eclipse.jdt.doc.isv/reference/api/org/e clipse/jdt/core/IClasspathEntry.html ) mentions possibility to use a folder with class files external to the workspace.
But this does not work. The Build Path configuration dialog allows only picking folders from workspace, but I have tried adding entry
<classpathentry kind="lib" path="/C:/test/classes"/>
directly to .classpath file in my project. The build path was considered OK, but the classes from the folder were not available on the project classpath. The interesting thing is, that when I specified a non-existing folder, I got a build path error and the project did not compile at all.
Same behavior observed in both E2.1 and E3.0M8.
Note: "Setting the Java build path" ( http://help.eclipse.org/help21/topic/org.eclipse.jdt.doc.isv/guide/jdt_api_class path.htm ) mentions that the class file folder should be inside the workspace only, which is a conflict with the documentation mentioned above. You should not edit the .classpath yourself. Go to the project properties>Java Build Path>Libraries>Add Class Folder>Create New Folder...>Advanced>
In the folder name, you put the name you want to see in the project. You check "Link to folder on the file system" and then you browse to the directory you want.
Click OK until you close the dialog. This should work. I see, so I must link the external folder into the workspace.
However that means that the documentation in IClasspathEntry is not right. I found this problem because I actually did this thing programatically (which now turns out to require two steps - linking the folder and then adding it to the classpath).
And second point is that the build path processor in fact considers the external folders somehow - as I wrote, it was checking whether the folder exists or not and did not produce any warning about that it is not supported (or that it is not a jar file).
And sorry for touching the .classpath file directly, that was just for testing :-)
Jerome - pls make change to spec to clarify this situation. Bug.Summery: Introduce Factory misses references in depending project

Lines.Line: 1. do 'Introduce Factory' on OldASTRewrite(ASTNode) in jdt.corext.dom
2. No updates in the test projects (org.eclipse.jdt.tests.ui) that require
jdt.ui and have references to the constructor
Bob, this is critical and must be fixed for M9. Can you please investigate.
Yes, a simple matter of using project rather than workspace scope in the search
for call sites. The fix is ready; I'll attach it.
Patch for jdt.ui against I2004-0504 to fix bug

Bug.WithStack:
20040420
1. do 'Introduce Factory' on OldASTRewrite(ASTNode) in jdt.corext.dom 2. No updates in the test projects (org.eclipse.jdt.tests.ui) that require jdt.ui and have references to the constructor Bob, this is critical and must be fixed for M9. Can you please investigate. Yes, a simple matter of using project rather than workspace scope in the search for call sites. The fix is ready; I'll attach it. Created attachment 10368 Patch for jdt.ui against I2004-0504 to fix bug
Trivial one-line patch to use workspace scope instead of project scope for the SearchEngine query. Created attachment 10369 Patch for jdt.ui.tests.refactoring against I2004-0504 to add JUnit test for bug fix Simply taking the workspace scope isn't the right thing to do since this will cause lots of grief if you have the same source twice in the workspace (within different projects or source folders). I changed the code so that the refactoring scope factory is used.
Additionally I had to go through all the test resources to add package declaration statements. Bob, when you create a CU for testing in a package p there must be a package declaration statement in the source code otherwise the Java model will not function correctly.
I released the additional test cases. Bob, can you please verify the code changes I made. Well of course I know that... I could swear I put package declarations in. Before attaching the patch file, I naturally ran all the JUnit tests with these modifications and they all passed (including the new multi-project test case).
Hmmm... I'm looking at the patch that added the JUnit tests and the resource files there *do* have a reasonable-looking package declaration.
I'm not sure what's going on here. I know you've probably got a lot on your plate right now, but can you check again?
On the other hand, if you're talking about the resources for bug #48504, it looks like I may indeed have forgotten to put in pkg decls there. Sorry for that one!
As for the changes to createSearchScope(), they look fine to me. All the old test cases didn't have package declaraion statements. The new ones do. To which "old ones" are you referring? I've looked at the original jdt.ui.tests.refactoring patch files in Bugzilla for all of my bugs over the last few months, and only the two resource/Java files ("A.java" and "B.java") for #48504 were missing pkg decls. All the others either had them, or didn't need them b/c they were in the default package.
Sorry to be a nudge, but if there really is something going on here, I want to know so I don't make the same mistake in the future. All the files in positive and negative didn't had package declaration statemens but where created in the a package p in the test cases. I added a package declaration statement to all those tests files.

Bug.Summery: "Collect object References" button disabled/displays message that it's not enabled
Bug.WithStack:
Launch an application with both profiling options "Memory/Leak analysis" and "Execution time analysis" checked.
You will see that the collect object references button will be disabled. (Actually, sometimes it's enabled, but then when you click on it, it will pop up a dialog saying that the chosen option is disabled and then grey the button out.) The button should be enabled. If you only run with Memory/Leak analysis checked, then it is enabled properly. Fixed along with #59288. closing
Bug.WithOutStack:
Launch an application with both profiling options "Memory/Leak analysis" and "Execution time analysis" checked.
You will see that the collect object references button will be disabled. (Actually, sometimes it's enabled, but then when you click on it, it will pop up a dialog saying that the chosen option is disabled and then grey the button out.) The button should be enabled. If you only run with Memory/Leak analysis checked, then it is enabled properly. Fixed along with #59288. closing

Bug.Summery: Allow searching all places in a project where it references a particular plugin
Bug.WithStack:
When using "Compute dependency extent" functionality in plug-in manifest editor, a list from the target plugin is presented. But at that point it is not possible to search for all the references to these classes in my plugin project (which I'd find useful most of the time). Instead I may only search references to one particular class (or interface or extension point) from the list.
The use-case "search for all places in my project where it references plugin x.y.z" is not easily doable (or I do not know the correct way). What you are asking for is already available.
When you get the full list of classes/interfaces, right-click on the entry that you want in the search view and choose "Find references in plugin x.y.z" from the context menu. I know about this feature but that's not enough for what I asked for.
To clarify - let's say I have plugin org.myplugin, which depends on plugin com.otherplugin and uses OtherClass1 and OtherClass2 from it. What I want to find out is all places in org.myplugin, which reference OtherClass1 _and_ OtherClass2.
Using Compute Dependency Extent shows me a list of "OtherClass1, OtherClass2". What I can do now with the functionality that's already present is search for references from org.myplugin to OtherClass1 _or_ OtherClass2.
Generalize on arbitrary number of classes (or extension points, which are also dependencies shown by ComputeDependencyExtent).
I fail in my use-case to show "all places in org.myplugin, which reference (depend on) com.otherplugin". I'm only able to look the dependencies on a single resource (class, ext. point) from com.otherplugin.
Feature request is valid, but not for 3.0 (M9 target is from Wassim's initial WORKSFORME annotation) This bug has not been considered in many years. Closing as WONTFIX. Please reopen if you are interested in contributing a patch.

Bug.Summery: Object references are not collected

Lines.Line: - set both Memory Analysis and Execution Time Analysis
- Under Memory Analysis, set show instance level info
- Under Execution Time Analysis set show instance level info
- Under Execution time analysis, if you set show execution stats, the Collect
Object refs button will be greyed out when you run.
- Under Execution time analysis, if you set show execution flow graphical
details, the collect obj refs button will be active when you run. However, when
you press it, the Object refs view will NOT be updated properly (ie: it won't

Bug.WithStack:
Tested with the M9 test driver. What I've noticed is that although I've checked both Memory Analysis and Execution Time Analysis the profiling agent has the following collection mode set:EXECUTION_FULL. Should it be not HEAP_AND_EXECUTION_FULL? Once I got past the problem of the collect obj refs button not being enabled (bug 59285), I had no problem taking heap dumps. Having both 'Memory Analysis' and 'Execution time Analysis' checked is actually what caused the Collect Obj Refs button to be disabled for me (if you only enabled 'Memory Analysis' it was enabled and the heap dump could be taken.) I just encountered this problem with Samson on his box. The object references button was enabled, but it wasn't doing anything when it was pressed. (Samson had both the Execution time and Memory Analysis options checked, plus some other details.) Changing the mode to Memory Analysis only seem to fix the problem. Specifically, it seems that the following config is causing the problem:
- set both Memory Analysis and Execution Time Analysis - Under Memory Analysis, set show instance level info - Under Execution Time Analysis set show instance level info
Further: - Under Execution time analysis, if you set show execution stats, the Collect Object refs button will be greyed out when you run. - Under Execution time analysis, if you set show execution flow graphical details, the collect obj refs button will be active when you run. However, when you press it, the Object refs view will NOT be updated properly (ie: it won't actually show any references).
(In the latter case, profiling to file shows that all the objReferences are sent as they should be, so it must be the UI that's getting into some weird state preventing it from updating the Object References view.) Fixed.
This was being caused by the recent change away from the TRACE_MODE=default RAC option. In order to set the agent collection mode, it was looking specifically for this default value, which caused the collection mode to not be set properly. The icon determines whether it should enable itself by a few criteria - collection mode being one of them. Closing.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Tested with the M9 test driver. What I've noticed is that although I've checked both Memory Analysis and Execution Time Analysis the profiling agent has the following collection mode set:EXECUTION_FULL. Should it be not HEAP_AND_EXECUTION_FULL? Once I got past the problem of the collect obj refs button not being enabled (bug 59285), I had no problem taking heap dumps. Having both 'Memory Analysis' and 'Execution time Analysis' checked is actually what caused the Collect Obj Refs button to be disabled for me (if you only enabled 'Memory Analysis' it was enabled and the heap dump could be taken.) I just encountered this problem with Samson on his box. The object references button was enabled, but it wasn't doing anything when it was pressed. (Samson had both the Execution time and Memory Analysis options checked, plus some other details.) Changing the mode to Memory Analysis only seem to fix the problem. Specifically, it seems that the following config is causing the problem:
- set both Memory Analysis and Execution Time Analysis - Under Memory Analysis, set show instance level info - Under Execution Time Analysis set show instance level info
Further: - Under Execution time analysis, if you set show execution stats, the Collect Object refs button will be greyed out when you run. - Under Execution time analysis, if you set show execution flow graphical details, the collect obj refs button will be active when you run. However, when you press it, the Object refs view will NOT be updated properly (ie: it won't actually show any references).
(In the latter case, profiling to file shows that all the objReferences are sent as they should be, so it must be the UI that's getting into some weird state preventing it from updating the Object References view.) Fixed.
This was being caused by the recent change away from the TRACE_MODE=default RAC option. In order to set the agent collection mode, it was looking specifically for this default value, which caused the collection mode to not be set properly. The icon determines whether it should enable itself by a few criteria - collection mode being one of them. Closing.

Bug.Summery: [launching] external tool builder names must be globally unique?
Bug.WithStack:
3.0 M7
it seems that external tool builder names must be globally unique i wanted to have 2 external tool builders for /usr/bin/make for 2 different projects, both called 'make clean' - eclipse would not allow me
this restriction seems unnecessary This is an artificial limitation in the launch framework, imposed by the launch dialog. The only real limitation is that two configs in the same directory/folder (metadata) cannot have the same name (since the name is used as the file name).
We should be able to relax this. If a configuration isn't shared, the name has to be unique because we store the configs in files in the same location (the metadata area).
For shared configs, we can get more complex. So long as the file location isn't the same, the names can be the same. But we need to make sure that when the user changes a shared config's location that we re-verify that there's no name collision. >If a configuration isn't shared, the name has to be unique because we store the >configs in files in the same location (the metadata area).
sounds like an implementation detail that surfaces as nuisance for users
Deferred, post 3.0. Too late for this change. As well, it creates problems in the LCD when configs have the same name (i.e. the tree needs to render more info to be able to distinguish them). Consider for 3.1 Deferred *** Bug 103029 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 107274 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 130204 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 135258 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 135258 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 154774 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 163303 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 165151 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Created attachment 54801 patch
This is a work in progress that allows configs to have the same name if stored in different locations. It enhances the way "local" configs are stored. Rather than storing them all in one directory in the metadata, a directory structure is created based on the resource that a configruation is stored with. It effectively gives configurations a namespace based on their resource mapping. So, two configs can have the same name if the're not associated with the same "container" resource.
It does not add UI support to distingusish between configs with the same name. What if launch configuration is not associated with any resource? Or what if it's associated with multiple resources?
P.S. Sorry, I didn't have time to look at the patch itself. No resource == default package (i.e. all configs that have no resource association share the same namespace).
Multiple resoruces == use the first resource (not sure what the rule should be here - probably should use the "deepest" resource in the association, but if it's cross project resources, then not sure what to do). As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you. *** Bug 365232 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** As requested by Denis Roy (see comment above), I would like to have this bug reopened, because it seems as if the patch has never been applied or is not functioning.
The issue still exists in Version: Indigo Service Release 1 Build id: 20110916-0149
Because this is an enhancement request, I would like to suggest an related enhancement which allows the use of a global external tool launcher by a logical reference (no file system soft link) instead of copying it to the project folder. (It could be another option besides creating a new builder or importing a global one). I think this is the actual reason why most people would like to have the same name for a builder in multiple projects. It would even allow to migrate the same project on different platforms without changing the external tool builder launcher each time you switch between them (consider for example different OSs or different tools doing the same thing). This would come in very handy e.g. for teams working on a common source code repository which contains the project configuration as well. (In reply to comment #20)
> Because this is an enhancement request, I would like to suggest an related > enhancement which allows the use of a global external tool launcher by a > logical reference (no file system soft link) instead of copying it to the > project folder. (It could be another option besides creating a new builder > or importing a global one). > I think this is the actual reason why most people would like to have the > same name for a builder in multiple projects. It would even allow to migrate > the same project on different platforms without changing the external tool > builder launcher each time you switch between them (consider for example > different OSs or different tools doing the same thing). This would come in > very handy e.g. for teams working on a common source code repository which > contains the project configuration as well.
Could you create a separate bug for the additional request? Latter enhancement request moved into seperate enhancement request (Bug: 400126). Is this really such a toughie?

driver used: WSWB 3.0M9 integration I20040413-200404151406 + hyades.runtime_3.0_20040419_0915.zip
to reproduce the problem: >Open Profiling perspective, and create a simple project in resouce navigator. >create a new Perfmom Data Collection Agent launch configuration, connect to 'localhost'(default) and browse to the newly created project >hit 'Apply' and 'Run'
nothing happen, no agent created.
looking at the .log file, see the following Exception. !SESSION Apr 20, 2004 12:06:39.205 --------------------------------------------- java.fullversion=J2RE 1.4.2 IBM Windows 32 build cndev-20040322 (JIT enabled: jitc) BootLoader constants: OS=win32, ARCH=x86, WS=win32, NL=en_US !ENTRY org.eclipse.hyades.perfmon 4 0 Apr 20, 2004 12:06:39.205 !MESSAGE Error starting perfmon agent trace !STACK 0 org.eclipse.swt.SWTException: Invalid thread access at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:2659) at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java(Inlined Compiled Code)) at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java(Inlined Compiled Code)) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.error(Display.java(Inlined Compiled Code)) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.checkDevice(Display.java(Compiled Code)) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.getActiveShell(Display.java:788) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.getActiveWorkbenchWindow (Workbench.java:581) at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.DebugUIPlugin.getActiveWorkbenchWindow (DebugUIPlugin.java:211) at org.eclipse.hyades.trace.internal.ui.TraceUIManager.showConsole (TraceUIManager.java:277) at org.eclipse.hyades.trace.internal.ui.TraceUIManager.registerLaunchProcess (TraceUIManager.java:181) at org.eclipse.hyades.trace.ui.UIPlugin.registerLaunchProcess (UIPlugin.java:92) at org.eclipse.hyades.perfmon.PerfmonGenericLoader$1.processLaunched (PerfmonGenericLoader.java:250) at org.eclipse.hyades.internal.execution.local.control.ProcessImpl.launch (ProcessImpl.java:161) at org.eclipse.hyades.perfmon.PerfmonGenericLoader.init (PerfmonGenericLoader.java:259) at org.eclipse.hyades.perfmon.PerfmonGenericLoader.<init> (PerfmonGenericLoader.java:63) at org.eclipse.hyades.perfmon.PerfmonModuleTrace$Init.run (PerfmonModuleTrace.java:626)

Bug.Summery: Deadlock between AllTypes cache and setClasspathContainer
Bug.WithStack:
I20040420
Deadlock happens because 1a. main thread locks JavaModelManager 1b. AllTypes cache locks via rule (some resources) 2a. main thread want lock for some resources that got locked in 1b 2b. AllTypes cache wants lock on JavaModelManager Created attachment 9716 thread dump Created attachment 9754 Just the two blocking threads It seems that the deadlock does not occur in the AllTypesCache code but inside jdt.core: the code to compute the resolved classpath seems to lock the JavaModelManager and some resources inconsistently. I've tried to aquire the JavaModelManager lock before starting a Search, but this wasn't too succesful and I don't think that this is the right approch anyway.
Your comment? This is a consequence of the thread safety protection we added to resolve bug 57886. Deferred container persistence until save operation is performed. Thus the blocking question is only asked outside the JavaModelManager lock.
Fixed *** Bug 59600 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Verified for 3.0 M9 with build I200405190010.
Bug.WithOutStack:
I20040420
Deadlock happens because 1a. main thread locks JavaModelManager 1b. AllTypes cache locks via rule (some resources) 2a. main thread want lock for some resources that got locked in 1b 2b. AllTypes cache wants lock on JavaModelManager Created attachment 9716 thread dump Created attachment 9754 Just the two blocking threads It seems that the deadlock does not occur in the AllTypesCache code but inside jdt.core: the code to compute the resolved classpath seems to lock the JavaModelManager and some resources inconsistently. I've tried to aquire the JavaModelManager lock before starting a Search, but this wasn't too succesful and I don't think that this is the right approch anyway.
Your comment? This is a consequence of the thread safety protection we added to resolve bug 57886. Deferred container persistence until save operation is performed. Thus the blocking question is only asked outside the JavaModelManager lock.
Fixed *** Bug 59600 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Verified for 3.0 M9 with build I200405190010.

Bug.Summery: Error dialog when importing remote log files.
Bug.WithStack:
Error dialog when importing remote log files.
The enclosed error dialog is displayed when attempting to import remote log files using either the rules or static log file parsers. Created attachment 9717 screen capture This defect is caused by running the Hyades Data Collection Engine using JDK 1.3.x or below. Since the Hyades Data Collection Engine does not ship Xalan, the Hyades XML serialization (e.g. DOM --> XML) is missing the Xalan dependency.
Since Hyades 3.0 is moving toward being JDK 1.4.x dependent, this defect is considered invalid. Closing. house keeping

Since the Hyades Data Collection Engine does not ship Xalan, the Hyades XML serialization (e.g. DOM --> XML) is missing the Xalan dependency.
Since Hyades 3.0 is moving toward being JDK 1.4.x dependent, this defect is considered invalid. Closing. house keeping

Bug.Summery: CTabFolder tabs should always have a border around them
Bug.WithStack:
Regardless of whether the SWT.BORDER style is set, CTabFolder should always draw something to box in all its tabs, that is, the clickable areas you can select to switch pages in the folder (not the content itself). Currently it just draws a vertical line after each tab and uses full surrounding graphic for only the active tab. Usually you can't tell because most places turn on SWT.BORDER but this has two bad effects:
- inactive tabs are squared off, not slightly rounded (simple tabs) or curvy (non-simple tabs). Except the first tab which bumps up against the border.
- SWT.NONE is pretty much useless because of this (I'll attach a screenshot to show this).
Also I'm hoping that once this change is made it will be more obvious that the inactive tab background colors should not be the same as the empty space surrounding the tabs, but that's a different bug entry. Created attachment 9720 Screenshot showing current CTabFolder with SWT.NONE style.
This is what it looks like currently without SWT.BORDER. I have the simple look turned on here but the non-simple look works the same way. Created attachment 9793 Patched CTabFolder with SWT.NONE style Created attachment 9794 Screenshot showing patched CTabFolder on the whole workbench. Created attachment 9795 Proposed patch for CTabFolder and CTabItem
This patch changes the way tabs are rendered to always draw the border around the tab, make the selected tab a little taller than the non-selected tabs, and add a small gap in between tabs. It also fixes bug 59296. It does not work with the curvy tabs, just the simple ones. Created attachment 9797 Proposed patch for TabFolderLayout
This change supports tabs of varying heights when deciding where to put the view toolbar. The screenshots look very promising. Although, I am having problems to apply the patch on the sources of CTabFolder / CTabItem (tryd it with 3.0 M8 and the latest nightly 3.0.49). Eclipse tells me that a lot of lines do not match with the patch.
Anyways this patch should get into the next Milestone. Are there any plans of doing so?
Regards, Ben This is not the desired appearance for multi-tab editors. For example, open a plugin.xml editor. We do not want the additional border showing around the tabs because this will give the UI a chiseled look.
The appearance of the CTabFolder is defined by the Eclipse Graphic Design and Usability team and will only be changed in 3.0 on request from them. Changes such as having the selected tab be larger than the other tabs or having space between the tabs will not be addressed in 3.0 unless requested by the UI design team. Sorry.

Bug.Summery: osgi plug-ins appear as (out of sync)

Lines.Line: 2. Window > Preferences > go to Plug-in Development > Target Platform

Bug.WithStack:
I20040420
1. Start fresh workspace 2. Window > Preferences > go to Plug-in Development > Target Platform
==> the list with plug-ins shows the 3 osgi plug-ins as (out of sync) *** Bug 59350 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** This is just a visual annoyance because the plugins in questions had their plugin.xml removed, and PDE's label provider was not ready for that.
This does not in any way affect self-hosting, classpath computation or any one of your favorite PDE-related activities. Fixed.

Bug.Summery: Silent failures when watchpoint cannot be set or is remvoed
Bug.WithStack:
Currently, CDT (v1.2.1), watchpoint representation could be misleading. When CDT fails to install a watchpoint in GDB or when a watchpoint is removed by GDB, the watchpoint still shows itself as being enabled in the breakpoint view. In reality, that watchpoint is not there and will no longer function. So it should either be deleted or be shown as disabled by CDT. Right now it still appears as enabled in the breakpoint view. This happens when one is setting up a watchpoint for a local variable and I find the global variable watchpoint to behave correctly.
In current CDT (1.2.1), watchpoint on a local variable can only be set when the variable is in view of the execution thread as GDB allows only local variable watchpoint to be set in such a way. The consequence is that once the variable is outside the scope of the thread, or when the program terminates, the local variable watchpoint is silently deleted in GDB. However, that watchpoint still shows up in CDT's watchpoint view and will not get re-installed again. Changed to support the following behavior: If watchpoint is set on a global variable it can be shared by multiple sessions and is persistent across sessions. If watchpoint is on a local variable (which possible to do by using the gdb console only) it applies to the particular session and will be deleted as soon as it goes out of scope.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Currently, CDT (v1.2.1), watchpoint representation could be misleading. When CDT fails to install a watchpoint in GDB or when a watchpoint is removed by GDB, the watchpoint still shows itself as being enabled in the breakpoint view. In reality, that watchpoint is not there and will no longer function. So it should either be deleted or be shown as disabled by CDT. Right now it still appears as enabled in the breakpoint view. This happens when one is setting up a watchpoint for a local variable and I find the global variable watchpoint to behave correctly.
In current CDT (1.2.1), watchpoint on a local variable can only be set when the variable is in view of the execution thread as GDB allows only local variable watchpoint to be set in such a way. The consequence is that once the variable is outside the scope of the thread, or when the program terminates, the local variable watchpoint is silently deleted in GDB. However, that watchpoint still shows up in CDT's watchpoint view and will not get re-installed again. Changed to support the following behavior: If watchpoint is set on a global variable it can be shared by multiple sessions and is persistent across sessions. If watchpoint is on a local variable (which possible to do by using the gdb console only) it applies to the particular session and will be deleted as soon as it goes out of scope.
